newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai copper futures end down on profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai copper futures end down on profit-taking.

text.p: Shanghai copper futures ended down on Thursday on profit-taking despite overnight gains on the London Metal Exchange (LME), traders said.
Selling by big copper producers triggered follow-up short positions and profit-taking, and saw the local red metal move against the LME, they said.
The most actively traded September 1997 contract ended at an intraday low of 23,800 yuan ($2,870) per tonne, losing 120 yuan. It opened at 24,010 and hit a high of 24,050 yuan per tonne.
June fell 200 yuan to 23,150, July 90 to 23,410, August 110 to 23,600, October 80 to 23,830 and November 70 to 23,830.
Combined volume rose to 36,270 tonnes from 19,890 tonnes.
LME copper ended Wednesday at $2,533 a tonne, and early trade on Thursday saw the price move around this strong level, supported by a stock drawdown of 3,550 tonnes.
Shanghai copper opened high but profit-taking and short-selling pushed prices down with most contracts closing at or near their intraday lows.
"Copper failed to stand firm above the 24,000-yuan level, indicating heavy selling pressure at that level," one trader said.
"Big copper producers were seen building short positions above the 24,000-yuan level, which hurt buyers' confidence and encouraged profit-taking and follow-up shorters," another trader said.
"Nor did the current physical copper price provide any support to the futures market," he said.
The price of physical copper is around 23,300 yuan per tonne in the Shanghai area.
Producers were not likely to change their policy of building short positions above 24,000 yuan unless they heard some strong market-moving news, some traders said.
But other traders said copper would rise again after the short-term correction.
Aluminium ended down across the board. June fell 50 to 15,300 yuan per tonne, July 50 to 15,500 and August 140 to 15,560 yuan per tonne.
Combined volume rose to 590 tonnes from 230 tonnes.
